posts.author: DMScreener
posts.content:
I've been thinking about Dragon lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about Dragon that came up in our game last night.

I'd love to hear everyone's experiences with Dragon and how it's worked in your games.

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about Dragon?

posts.author: RangerDanger
posts.content:
In our last session, we encountered a Basilisk and tried to use Dragon to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

Our table uses a house rule for Dragon where we allow more flexibility in how it's applied. It's been working well so far.

The way I understand the rules for Dragon, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about Dragon. Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: NaturalTwenty
posts.content:
The best campaign moment I ever had involved creative use of balance to solve what seemed like an impossible puzzle.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use balance to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

When DMing, I like to use balance as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about balance. Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: BardTales
posts.content:
In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how Dragon works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

In our last session, we encountered a Owlbear and tried to use Dragon to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that Dragon functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

In my campaign, we had a situation with Dragon that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.
